issues.title: racking faults may not be sufficient to detect problems & proactively prevent  incidents
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
> > (4) Tracking faults may not be sufficient to detect problems
> and
> > proactively prevent  incidents. For example, performance
> degradation
> > may not be detected with usual  fault management.
> 
> Hmmm. I'm not clear what you are proposing here.
> I would say that there is a good deal of policy at every stage
> ...
> - Not every Event is an Occurrence
> - Not every Occurrence is indicative of a Fault
> - Not every Fault gives rise to a Problem, and a Problem may
> arise from a set of Faults
> - Not every Problem results in an Incident, and an Incident may
> derive from multiple Problems All of those steps need "value
> judgements" also known as Policy.
> 
> While "Incident Prevention" is highly desirable, it may not be
> easy to achieve because:
> - A single Event may lead directly to an Incident. No scope for
> detecting a potential escalation and preventing the Incident. All
> that remains is remedial action.
> - There is need for a knowledge base (possibly feeding ML) to map
> a "non-obvious" set of Events into an imminent Incident.
> 
> This is all good material for discussion, but perhaps it does not
> belong in a terminology document? Something for the anomaly
> framework?
> 

[Med] You are probably right that some of this can be captured in the anomaly framework.
